I hope this story reaches you.  I was buying a new car in Phoenix, Az.  I had a Nasa ballcap on, as I almost always do.  The finance guy at the dealership comments on it.  We immediately start talking the James Webb telescope.  I ask him if he follows "Everyday Astronaut" on YouTube  as I do.  He says absolutely...awesome channel. Tim, this video does a great job in explaining your journey of learning about "rocket science". I invite you to take one more major step on this path:
- This is NOT actually rocket science.

The utter irony in the cliche "It's not rocket science" is that "rocket science" itself is not rocket science. People who use that term either don't understand the difference between science and engineering, or they know but don't care. But the difference is quite simple:
- Science is learning about nature (from the Latin scientia, meaning knowledge),
- Engineering is building cool stuff to help us do things ...like land on the Moon.

The word 'engineering' has the same root as the word 'ingenious'. You created something that is clever, and useful. The difference between engineering & science is along the lines of the difference between invention & discovery. Science finds out more about things that were already there. Engineering makes new things so you can do new things. Conceiving of, designing, building and launching rockets is the creation of new things. It is not science at all.

NASA is only doing science when they use space probes to take measurements of natural objects found across the Solar System and beyond, which happens long after the rocket boosters have been jettisoned. It is doing science with the help of rockets, in the same kind of way that a bunch of PhDs ride a bus to their lab. The bus enabled them to do the science. But it would be absolutely silly to say they are doing "Bus Science". The bus was just the vehicle that was engineered and got them into the position where they were able to use their instruments to take scientific measurements.

And this is the same role rocket boosters play when NASA does a scientific investigation. The rocket is the thing that was engineered which enabled your scientific instruments to be in a position to take their measurements. So what people mean when they say this term, whether they know it or not, is:

- Rocket engineering.

Tim, it is clear that you are passionate about educating people through your videos. And a key role of education is to identify and isolate myths, and then be diligent when separating fact from fiction. It is like stacking blocks when building a pyramid. If some of those blocks are spongy instead of rock solid, if you continue on your merry way without making the effort to fix things, then this is setting ourselves up for a big fall at some point down the line.

I've long been a huge fan of your channel, and will look forward to more great stuff from you in the future. Thanks for the amazing corner of YouTube you've built here.

I was curious as to whether you would end up doing some videos regarding the SLS/Orion/Artemis lunar program. I’ve noticed that you’ve done a number of videos centered around SpaceX launchers and I understand why you have. They shown a capability that may allow space exploration to be much easier. However, I feel that the Artemis Program may have a lot of potential. I understand that  SLS is not reusable and would probably have been a lot more useful if it launched in 2017 as planned but as far as I know it may allow us to go back to the moon a lot sooner than any current option. I do not think it is the best vehicle for lunar exploration but it seems like a good start. They may even start using Starship/Superheavy for lunar exploration— a task I think it would be better suited for than Mars exploration. Only God knows what incredible things could result from this program. Because of this I would really appreciate some videos centered around SLS/Orion. Please don’t take this as me being vehemently against SpaceX and in total support of SLS.

The biggest challenge to space colonization isn’t the technical. It will fail because the economic and political constraints are vastly more ominous. The current space narrative is euphoric, rightfully, over elegant and amazing achievements answering the How. But the current narratives addressing the why are horrendously flimsy ... bordering on mystical. We ought to focus much more attention on the why. Apollo was cancelled for a reason.
